comments:
I was trying to get Cactus to run with the WTP and ran into the following
problem.  My information was taken from this
tutorial:http://eclipse.org/webtools/community/tutorials/CactusInWTP/CactusInWTP.html
 It seems that individual cactus test do indeed work, but running a test suite
containing cactus tests fails.  Here are the details.

When right clicking on a test suite from the Package Explorer such as the one
below and selecting run on server, it opens up the web browesr and points to a
url of the fully qualified name of the test suite class:

package edu.harvard.mgh.lcs.tests.inbox;

import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;

public class AllTests {

	public static Test suite() {
		TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("run all inbox tests...");
		suite.addTestSuite(TestTestServlet.class);
		suite.addTestSuite(TestInboxDataReader.class);
		suite.addTestSuite(TestXMLTool.class);
		return suite;
	}
}

All of these test suites extend org.apache.cactus.ServletTestCase.  When trying
to right click on the AllTests.java in the Package Explorer and selecting Run as
JunitTest it opens up the JUnit plugin but throws the following error:

Yeah I see the problem. Eclipse can only tell that a class is a valid cactus
test by checking if it extends ServletTestCase. A suite does not necessarily do
that. While I think that is a horrible abuse of the supposed composition rules
of junit, it appears that junit allows you to have suites that aren't TestCases.
Ugh. 

Since junit support it, I suppose we have to, so I will look into detecting
suites correctly with run-on-server. As a work-around, just declare your class
as an instance of ServletTestCase and it should work.

returns an junit.framework.Test and if they have one, they are run as a cactus
test case.
